-ELISA LOADS TOWELS INTO A LAUNDRY VAN. 78D
-STRICKLAND ENTERS THE COMPLEX. GOES BY THE GUARD SHACK.
-VIEW FROM CARGO AREA IN CINEMA. IN THE BACK ALLEY GILES

dialogues.speaker: GILES / NARRATOR
dialogues.text: If I spoke about it- If I did- what would I tell you, I wonder? Would I tell you about the time...? It happened a long time ago- in the last days of a fair Prince's reign... Or would I tell you about the place? A small city near the coast but far from everything else... Or would I tell you about her? The princess without voice... (beat) Or perhaps I would just warn you of the about the truth of these facts and the tale of love and loss and the monster that tried to destroy it all... Camera pushes and we see: An entire apartment underwater. Objects and furniture float, gently suspended, defying gravity. Asleep on/above her bed -- half floating, half weighed do ELISA. Roughly 30, but ageless, with child-like eyes, dar lush hair and a thin, beautiful mouth slightly curved int satisfied smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slowly settles/drifts down on the mattress below as a early digital alarm clock lazily floats over a night tabl nearby... SUDDENLY: The alarm goes off! 1

dialogues.speaker: PM
dialogues.text: -Elisa opens her eyes. Lifts the mask, looks around: No w at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1c Slowly, she gets up. An ambulance red light briefly illuminates the apartment, its siren fading rapidly. Barefoot, she heads to the bathroom: We see that light is emanating from her FLOORBOARDS. Music and dialogue leaks up through the floorboards too. She readies the bathtub

dialogues.speaker: DIALOGUE
dialogues.text: “... No God could be pleased with the death of a child at the altar...” Camera goes through floor into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -the ornate ceiling- and into- The cinema: The STORY OF RUTH plays to an- -almost empty theater- One patron or two are asleep. TITLE: THE SHAPE OF WATER. INT. ELISA'S APARTMENT - SAME ic Elisa drops three eggs into a pot of boiling water and heads for the bathroom. On the way there- she picks up an egg timer and casually winds it. INT. ELISA’S BATHROOM 2 She disrobes- Revealing: On both sides of her neck: two keloid scars, diagonal and about three inches long.

dialogues.speaker: DIALOGUE
dialogues.text: ”...Who’s the man?” (beat) Mahlon, the Judean artisan...” The voices from below continue as she steps into the bath Water overflows and hits the tiled floor. She sinks in. A deep sigh. She sets the egg timer to TWO MINUTES. She sighs. Then rubs her hand with soap, plants her two on the base of the tub, sighs again and goes to work on herself, gently, slowly- -but with the timer ticking away- She’s almost there when the timer DINGS. INT. KITCHEN, ELISA’S APARTMENT - SAME 3 A WALL CLOCK- its minute hand slides into position- TACK! 10:55 PM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa rips off a leaf from a wall calendar and opens a window, letting the fresh air in. Her hair is wet and she nervously looks at the clock on the wall. The Calendar leaf back reads: “Time is but a river flowin from our past.”

dialogues.speaker: CLACK
dialogues.text: Elisa stares at a WALL OF SHOES. Chooses a GREEN PAIR. Shines them, quietly- alone- at the table. Puts them on. Another siren goes by.

dialogues.speaker: CLACK
dialogues.text: She takes out 3 hardboiled eggs- still steaming- out of a pot. Uses the calendar sheet to pack one, plus saltines a small mustard and a half pickle sandwich on a paper bag. Two eggs and a half sandwich go onto a small plate. She undoes the three locks on her door (light & music intensifies still emanating from the floorboards) and-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -exits her apartment. We see the “shadowing” of old brass letters -some are still there- they read “DELIVERIES” She goes to the door directly across from hers (similar s “PROCESSING”). A TV can be heard inside. She uses a key to let herself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of books. ENTIRELY full of them. Here and there are finished illustrations. Large original art from ADVERTISEMENTS. Two cats- SNOWFLAKE and LILLIE stroll laz

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: (over sirens) Did the sirens wake you up? Hard at work at a drawing table- is GILES: late 60's, ref and prim: wool vest, bow tie and tortoiseshell glasses. W he speaks he has a ever-so-slight stutter (which gets wor when he gets nervous). GILES (CONT’D) It's a fire. The chocolate factory. It rained a little - not enough to put it out... Rains are late this year... You smell that? Toasted cocoa. Tragedy and delight- hand in hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giles is coloring an illustration of a happy family aroun BRIGHT RED JELL-O MOLD. A sign reads: THE FUTURE IS HERE! On his forehead: THREE pairs of eyeglasses. He raises one lowers another one- grabs a brush. We see a toupee restin top of an acrylic paint box. Elisa puts the eggs and carrot down on a side table. He caresses/taps her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, Darling child. I'd waste away to nothing without you looking after me. I am the proverbial starving artist am I not? Shirley Temple dances on the stairs with Bojangles on “Th Little Colonel”. GILES (CONT’D) Oh- watch that- Bojangles- the stair dance. He slides his chair to see better.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you look at that? Very hard to do. Cagney did it- different- but beautiful- we should watch that one day

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa looks at the TV. Does a few tap steps. Sirens go by

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Elisa: Wake me up when you come back. Breakfast’s on me, Child. He goes back to his painting. Looks in the mirror and smi Paints the smile on the father figure in the ad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both sides of the corridor are blocked by FILM CANS. Elisa- low heeled shoes in one hand and a paper sandwich in the other- moves past the cans and reaches a red door. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands at the top of a fire escape. A breeze blows by The city lights glow in the distance. Looks at her watch: 10:55 ELISA climbs down. She exits past the ARCADE CINEMA MARQU She takes the steps in Bojangles fashion. She takes the steps in Bojangles fashion. The cinema owner, MR. ARZOUMANIAN, is changing the marque lettering for THE STORY OF RUTH, helped by an ASSISTANT.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARZOUMANIAN
dialogues.text: Elisa- when yoo bring the rent- stay for the bible moovie, eh? Theatre's empty... A FIRE ENGINE SCREAMS BY- On the horizon- A couple of blo away: the fire: A Glowing SIGN Sputters: ANNELY’S chocola A few people hurry towards the scene. Elisa crosses the street.

dialogues.speaker: 10A
dialogues.text: al 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa looks at a shoe store window. On display on a littl rotating platform: a pair of SILVER DANCE shoes. She star whistling a happy tune. Elisa dances around- and then sits down on- a bus bench i front of an appliance store. A CLOCK signals 11:05 On TV, over her whistle: MARTIN LUTHER KING. KENNEDY. RUS SATELLITES. CUBAN MISSILE CRISIS on other monitors. THEN- WAVING AMERICAN FLAG. PROGRAMMING ENDS. The bus arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa, still whistling. Almost entirely alone, on the bus (except for a FAT GUY snoring) looking out the window wit great longing. POV Industrial landscape passes by- reflections of fire a smoke against blue steel night sky. She uses her beret and scarf as a pillow. She closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUS drives by a huge clock and plaque that reads: OCCAM AEROSPACE RESEARCH CENTER. The time: 11:55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SQUARE, SQUAT concrete structure. Employees rush toward the building. ELISA climbs out of the bus- walks in. THRONGS OF WORKERS walk out-

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 12
dialogues.text: 12a 13 14 INT. ELEVATOR - NIGHT 12a Elisa in an elevator- goes down, down, down until it open into: Her watch: 11:58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WORKERS are moving out. A GOLF CART arrives with MP’s Elisa runs and barely makes it. Yolanda, a Latin girl, protests. A PUNCH CLOCKS, Standing in line we see ZELDA, a plump African American woman in her 30’s. She signals Elisa to in. Elisa runs and barely makes it. Yolanda a Latin girl, protests.

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: Hey- watch it, Dummy!!

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Leave her alone, Woman. I was keeping her place.

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: I get reported- I come looking for you and the mute...

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: You do that, Yolanda. You do that. Elisa checks in-

dialogues.speaker: CLACK
dialogues.text: cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa, Zelda and others get dressed in their JANITORIAL a KITCHEN / SERVICE garments. Change their shoes to low-heeled ones. All around them: Propaganda posters: “Loose Lips Sink Shi ete  15

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: My feet are killin’ me already- we ain't started and my feet are already killin’ me-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 cleaning ladies walk down the corridor in 2 lines of 3. They split off and walk into the adjacent labs. Behind th Elisa and Zelda follow and continue down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: I wear ‘em low-heeled shoes and it hurts just the same. My toes get all bunched up- and I feel like dyin’. Lord. Zelda and Elisa push into a long corridor full of SLAUGHTERHOUSE-STYLE DOORS, each bearing a number and a letter (B-67, C-25, etc). A GROUP OF SCIENTISTS walks alongside a MAN IN A CANVAS ASTRONAUT SUIT. They carry a multitude of canvas DUCTS extruding from it. About a DOZEN MP's guard the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa removing a piece of chewing gum. Zelda empties a WA BASKET.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA,
dialogues.text: Made Brewster pigs in a blanket tonight before leavin’. Fresh dough- the good sausages- thick- and Boy, he just ate ‘em up. (beat) No thank-yous- no yum-yums- not a peep, tho- Man is silent as the grave. But if farts were flattery, honey- he would be Shakespeare-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zelda and Elisa empty waste baskets.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Then I get home and I make him breakfast. Bacon and eggs and buttered toast. I butter the man’s toast, Elisa. Both sides- As if he were a child... And I don’t get a “Thank You”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zelda picks up a waste basket and a few pieces of paper-

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Hey- Lou- Lou! You boys mind throwing the trash in the bin? That's what it’s for... A BESPECTACLED MAN (Dr. BOB HOFFSTETLER) measures the temperature of the water with a long, industrial thermome He eyes Zelda.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes. That's what it’s for... Hard to believe, uh?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Alright. Alright. Sorry Zelda. Elisa and Zelda mop and sweep around a group of workers readying a big Filter/storage TANK of massive proportions next to a tiled HOLDING POOL. Roughly 20 men working at the same time. Fleming supervises the entire operation. The WORKERS are making a mess. Elisa signs Zelda.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: I don’t know Honey. I don’t know what they’re doing. (purposefully loud) Mostly making a Goddam mess is what I'd say... Hoffstetler whispers in Fleming’s ear.  10

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: (dabs his nose) Zelda, please- Watch the volume. And, there’s no call for the blaspheme, please-

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Yessir, sorry, Mr. Fleming, Sir-

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: (claps his hands) A moment of your time- Today, we will be receiving a new team and asset here in T-4. This here is Dr. Robert Hoffstetler... Zelda and Elisa look at each other. FLEMING (CONT’D) I don’t want to bolster - or overstate the matter- (proud laughter) -but this may be the most sensitive asset ever to be housed in this facility... Hoffstetler looks at Elisa. Everybody suddenly turns to attention. The sliding steel opens and MP’s pour in- Fleming thumbs them out. The door slowly slides opens and Zelda and Elisa pick up their carts and- as they exit- -they see a group of SPECIALISTS wheel a MASSIVE STEEL CYLINDER into the room. It’s twice the size of an iron lu and more elaborate. It is escorted by 4 MP's, and a square-jawed, steely-eyed dressed in a black, immaculate suit and tie: RICHARD STRICKLAND, 30's. In his right hand: an electric CATTLE PROD. The CYLINDER SHAKES!! SOMETHING LARGE MOVES INSIDE!! IT HOWLS!! A WEBBED HAND slams against the glass!!! A WEBBED PALM HITS THE GLASS!! Elisa jumps, startled.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: (to Fleming) They have to leave-  19 11

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Yes- yes-

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: You: help me move the cylinder into the compressor! There! They exit. Elisa sees a large form moving in the tank as -close the door.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. MEN’S BATHROOM - NIGHT 19

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Will you look at this? Elisa removes dirty towels from the multiple towel racks puts on fresh ones. Zelda points to the urinals.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look- Some of the best minds in our country- peeing all over the floor in this here facility. (beat) There's pee freckles on the ceiling!! How do they get it up there? ZELDA resumes mopping the checkered floor.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just how big a target do they need, you figure? They get enough practice that’s for sure. My Brewster, no one ever called him a great mind, even he hits the can seventy percent of the time. Suddenly, Strickland enters. In his hands: the cattle pro and a plastic bag of GREEN HARD CANDY. He places them on sink. They start to leave, but -

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: No. No. That’s alright... Go on- He washes his hands with the precision and care of a surg preparing to operate.  12

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ladies seem to be chatting enjoyably. Girl talk no doubt. Don't mind me. He makes eye contact with Elisa. Chews on the candy. Methodically. ELISA looks at the cattle prod. STRICKLAND (CONT’D) Look but don’t touch- (beat) That lovely dingus there is an Alabama Howdy-do... Strickland goes to the urinal and proceeds to piss- his h clenched in a fist, rest on both his hips.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Molded grip handle. Low-current, High-voltage electric shock cattle prod- That's for you to know, not to tell. You can hear his stream bouncing off the tile. ZELDA winc looks at Elisa.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm Strickland. Security.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Fleming's security.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Not while I’m here. On the stressed word, a momentary hitch in his stream.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saw you both at 1-4.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: We're cleared, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: I know. I checked. (beat) Doesn't it get lonely? The graveyard shift?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Gets quiet. That’s for sure.  19a 198 13 She offers him a clean towel. “NO”

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Man washes his hands before or after tending to his needs. That tells you a lot about that man. (beat) He does it both times? Points to a weakness of character... Picks up the rod. Weirdly beams at the two cleaners.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies? Very pleasant chatting with you both. Elisa notices a small drop of Red blood left behind by th cattle prod. It lazily extends on the wet, white surface the sink. cur TO: OMITTED 19a INT. “B” CORRIDOR - SAME 198 SWEET LORRAINE by Jon Erik Kellso starts. Elisa stands in front of door T-4. She takes out her clearance card and is about to use it but stops. The door opens. It’s HOFFSTETLER.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: May I help you? He removes surgical gloves. She moves back.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh! You're... not in uniform- Did you forget something-? Inside? She signs: “Excuse me” And walks away.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait- Wait! Hoffstetler watches her go  19c 20 21 14 INT. BUS - DAWN 19c Elisa leans her head on the window. Dawn bathes her. The light grows and grows- cleansing and magical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy streets. A VAN Pulls up- Out climb Giles and Elisa.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m wearing the hair. Watch out for that car... Giles straightens his toupee (now on his head) Elisa sign

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does it look good? They cross the street towards "DIXIE DOUG PIES.” cur TO: INT. “DIXIE DOUG PIES” DINER - DAY 21 Giles and Elisa stand before a glass and Stainless-steel, VENDING COLUMN/DISPLAY.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: It was eternal, see? Tantalus never even achieved the escape of death. The fruit on the branches was always just out of reach... His gaze drifts subtly to the PIE GUY at the register. He manly, masculine, like a construction worker. With pie.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank yeew. ¥’all come back, y’heah? Elisa watches Giles watching the guy, his glances filled longing.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: ...the water in the stream always receded just when he stooped to drink. And that's why we say things like, look at those tantalizing pies— (Elisa signs) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t like the colors either, but they taste alright. Try it. My treat. You want cold milk? At the COUNTER:

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Welcome to Dixie Doug’s, folks. That’1l be all?

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: For the moment.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Hey- I’ve seen you in here before, right?

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Oh, well- I- yes- I’ve been here. A couple of times as a matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Partial to key lime pie?

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: A craving I indulge in. It cannot possibly be good for me. Nothing I like is...

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Oh, no- It’s a mighty fine pie, key lime.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: And the color is so vivid!!

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Vivid! Now, there's a word I- there’s a word for ya...

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: A vivid word! It most certainly is. Elisa rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And would you be the famous “Dixie Doug” himself?

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Heck, no. Pies are trucked down throughout the country. It's called “franchising”, see? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s thirty-two Dixie Doug’s all over the country. He indicates the illuminated glass column that rotates to display the pies. He shrugs. PIE GUY (CONT’D) They give us the spinners, the signage- That there’s “Pie Boy” our mascot. They tell us what we gotta say- What to wear and such— there's a manual lays it all out. They figured out what people like, scientifically. I don't really talk that way, I'm from Ottawa.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: You had me completely fooled. (beat) “That 's-a-great-a-pie...” The Little guy is Italian is he?!

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: I guess so-

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: How clever! He watches Pie Guy pack them up, admiring his muscular ar Finished, Pie Guy looks up smiling.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Well, Thank yewww. Y'all come back now, y'heah? 22 EXT. GILES’ APARTMENT - DAY 22 They eat their pie and watch NAME THAT PRICE (or any morn/noon game show). Cats beg for pie.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: “y'all come back” Do you think he meant it? He had noticed me- you heard that yourself. Elisa rolls her eyes. Stops eating.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, this pie is rather sordid, but- Don’t spit it out- We could try a different flavor next time.  23 17 Elisa hands him the half-eaten pie and wipes her green to wa napkin. GILES (CONT’D) Well- you wanna save it- for later? Elisa channel-surfs: EARLY CIVIL RIGHTS PROTESTS ON THE N He puts the pie away in the fridge- (We see that there ar about half a dozen half-eaten multi-colored pie slices) H pours the rest of the milk on a cat’s plate.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looks at TV protests) Dear God- Change that awfulness- I don’t want to see all that- ELISA CHANGES CHANNELS to Betty Grable Dances PRETTY BABY from Coney Island. GILES moves the antenna around until t image is clear. Elisa gives him “thumbs up”

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There- Now- That’s better... Oh, would you look at Betty! To be young and beautiful. If I could take this brain of mine- this heart- and put in it- If I could go back in time, when I was eighteen- I didn’t know anything about anything- I- would give myself a bit of advice, I tell you- He sighs. She signs. GILES (CONT’D) I'd say: Take better care of your teeth and fuck. A lot more. She elbows him.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's very good advice While sitting, he tap-dances. Elisa joins him in a beauti little foot choreography- without leaving the sofa. Music overpowers the upcoming scene. cur TO: INT. ELISA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT 23 Alarm goes off: 10:45 PM. Elisa opens her eyes. Gets up.  24-260

dialogues.speaker: 26B
dialogues.text: 27 18 EGG TIMER in the F.G. In the B.G. Elisa taking care of business in the bathtub

dialogues.speaker: BOILING EGGS
dialogues.text: Calendar ripping SHINING SHOES. PUTTING THEM ON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa leans on the seat in front of her on the bus

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: (prelap) Short people are mean. Mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zelda empties the WASTE BASKETS in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Short people are mean... mean... You listen to me- they have a grudge- a big chip on their tiny little shoulders. I’ve never met a short man that stays nice all the way through, no, Sir- mean little backstabbers, all of ‘em. Maybe it’s the air down there, not enough oxygen or something. ELISA, sweeps - Keeping an eye on - T-4. ZELDA (CONT’D) My Brewster- he’s no Towering Titan- and he never raises his chin. He gets angry- you get the eyes. But the chin stays down... They hear gunshots. And screams. Muffled voices. 1-4! The door bursts open. They see FIGURES moving in the distance: urgent, hushed. hurry down the corridor  28 28a 19 They see STRICKLAND stagger out - clasping his bleeding h Blood squirts from it!!

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: Help! He’s losing blood! Find something for a tourniquet. Two MP’s rush towards Hoffstetler. He looks at ELISA- then presses an EMERGENCY BUTTON-

dialogues.speaker: BAMMMM
dialogues.text: -HEAVY STEEL DOORS shut the area hermetically.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Come on. Come on. Let them help them. Come on Elisa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa and Zelda pick up food from an automat. Yolanda eat a bench nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Think the Russians broke in? I don't think so. And If they did, Duane’s meatloaf will kill them all, honey. BENCHES: They eat. Elisa seasons an egg from her bag. 28A

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: It was two shots- you hear'em? ELISA raises three fingers. Zelda steals tater-tots from Elisa's tray and surgically removes the bacon from her ow meatloaf.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright- Three- and that scream. Heavens. Whatever goes on in this place...

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: (approaching) You two. Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Now, Mr Fleming, Sir? Any chance we might conclude our dinner?  29 30 20

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Now. Grab your carts and bring your code cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa and Zelda hurry BEHIND Fleming. They drag their trolleys behind with stern efficiency. They stop in front 1-4. Fleming’s nose is still runny.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Heavens to Betsy: we’re in a pickle. We’re in a real pickle now... He punches their cards into a CLEARANCE READER by the doo It beeps. The machine clacks and the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: You will have exactly twenty minutes, to render this- this lab immaculate and so on and so forth. Do you understand? Twenty minutes. He dabs his nose and exits. The place is covered in blood THE CYLINDER is now open attached to a large PUMP... An operating table is in the center of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Sweet dancing Jesus on the head of a pin- what went on in here? That's blood, hon- I tell you- may be all gunked up- But that’s blood... The cattle prod lies on the floor. Zelda pours water and starts mopping the blood. ZELDA (CONT’D) Help me mop it, Hon. Sooner we get out of here the better... Elisa throws one last bucket of water under a counter. -as the water flows back, it carries- TWO SEVERED HUMAN FINGERS.  31 21 Zelda picks up one-

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That a cigar? -a gold wedding band falls off of it. It rolls away. ZELDA (CONT’D) Aaagh!! Don’t touch that!! It’s a finger!! They’re all fingers!! (beat) I'm gonna call somebody. Stay here, Honey. Jesus Lord, fingers. She leaves- Elisa stays. She looks for the gold band. She looks inside the cylinder: A drop of water floats in water. She sees- -a figure, crouching in the dark: A slender, sleek AMPHIB MAN. Looking at her. Varied markings seems to glow and outline its body. Elisa’s shocked but not scared. The bleeding creature makes direct eye contact with her. Its EYES kick back light, like a coyote’s caught in the headlights. She moves towards it- cautiously. The creature hisses at and cowers. The lab door slides open- ZELDA and TWO MP’s rush in. The Amphibian man retreats.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are the fingers? Elisa offers him the paper bag. HAND ME DOWN MY WALKING C by B Goodman starts. INT. GILES’ APARTMENT - DAWN 31 Giles readies a CEREAL BOX and a bottle of milk.  32 22

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: I do believe you, darling, but are you sure it was alive? I once saw a mermaid- in a carnival tent. It was a monkey sewn to the tail of a fish. Looked real to me. Elisa scribbles: “Person/Fish” Giles serves her a plate.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I apologize. But I have a deadline- You know the Corn Flakes- they were created as a cure for masturbation. She pushes the plate away. He pushes it back. “Eat” GILES (CONT’D) It doesn’t work. Giles looks at a TV GUIDE. GILES (CONT’D) Oh, Alice Faye just started... Elisa switches channels: a scene in a Dance Hall with Ali Faye singing “You'll never know...” She stops eating the cereal. GILES (CONT’D) She was a huge star- And one day- one day she just couldn't take the bullshit, the backstabbing, anymore and she just walked away from everything. Just walked away- To live the way she wanted to- Giles dances a few steps to picks up his drawing- shows i Elisa. GILES (CONT’D) Ta-da! You like it? It’s not bad, is it? For being shit? Now, eat, go to bed. Rest- I get paid- we get pie! OK, not pie. I get pie. You get whatever you want. My treat. Wish me luck. He heads out. Elisa watches intently as Alice Faye croons

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A classy AD AGENCY. GILES hands the finished drawing to BERNARD (60's, well-groomed and dressed)  BERNIE. Green. They want the gelatin to be green now.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: But I was told red.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: New concept. All the new flavors are green: Celery, apple, Italian. That’s the future now. Green. An ELEGANT SECRETARY gives him a document to a Pantone swatch.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And they want them happier- the family.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Happier? The Father looks like he- he just discovered the missionary position... And the kids look like the have electrodes up their- What are they happy about?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Giles.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: What are they happy about?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: The future, Giles. (shift) Sorry, you know how it is. You do what they say, then they change everything. Too bad- this is nice work.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: It is nice work, isn’t it? One of my best. Giles nods, gravely. Bernie moves closer.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: How are you holding up? Are you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Not a drop. 23 sign. Hands him  33 34 24 BERNIE. Getting any work since you left Klein & Saunders?

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Since I was asked to leave. By you.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: We're not gonna get into that now. I like you. You know I do. Giles nods. BERNIE (CONT’D) Are you painting? Your own art? That well dried a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: I want back, Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: We'll see. Now- do this. The client wanted photographs. Photographs’s what’s coming- I sold them on this- Can you have it Monday? Green?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa pushes her cart down the corridor. Stops in front o 4. Hoffstetler and his LAB CREW exit. She takes her lunch opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters. The lab is quiet. She notices that a side hatch from the cylinder is open towards the holding pool. She hears a metallic noise. Moves towards the pool The water ripples. Chains clink. The three long chain lin emerge from the waterline. She sits down on the edge of the pool. She opens her lunc box and peels an egg- slowly. She watches the water move, finishes peeling it. She take bite.  34a 25 The Amphibian Man’s head emerges from the water. They stare at each other. He submerges towards her. The chains grow taut- they are attached to his neck. Then the creature is revealed in full: beautiful, Majesti Pure. She extends her arm: presents another egg to him. It hiss expanding his gills!! She recoils. Slowly she places it on the edge of the pool She offers the egg, signing “egg” toward it. The creature grabs the egg with its webbed hand and swims away with it. She watches his swim.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Zelda is in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Elisa. Elisa signs.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What am I doing here? What are you doing here? Elisa signs ZELDA (CONT’D) Okay. Cleaning. Hey honey, Mr. “I pee with my hands on my hips” wants to see us both. I don’t know why. Lord it better be short, because it is late and my feet are killing me. OMITTED 34a  35 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRICKLAND’S sitting down in his office (his fingers cove by clean bandages with a stain of blood and iodine)- he l pale and pissed. Behind him: a bank of security monitors.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: (reads a file) Zelda D. Fuller. How long have you two known each other, Zelda?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: About Ten years, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: No siblings, Zelda?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: No, Sir...

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: That’s not common, is it? For your people?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Momma died after me- After I was born.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: What does the “D” stand for? Elisa and Zelda sit in front of him, like girls at the principal's office.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: My “D"? Delilah, Sir- on account of the bible.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Dee-Li-lah. . .

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Beg your pardon? Strickland takes a HARD GREEN CANDY from a plastic bag. S on it.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Delilah- she betrays Samson- Lulls him to sleep, cuts his hair- Philistines torture him, humiliate him- burn his eyes out. Turned him into a thing-  27

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Guess my momma didn’t read the good book close enough. .

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: And you- (reads Elisa's file) Elisa... Elisa Esposito. Doesn't Esposito means “Orphan”? She nods. STRICKLAND (CONT’D) (reads file) Our Lady of Sorrows Orphanage in Putnam... Putnam?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: They found her- by the river- in the water...

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: That what they told you, uh? Elisa nods.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was you that found my fingers? She nods. Hands him back his ring. Puts it on the other h STRICKLAND (CONT’D) Three hours in surgery - They rebuilt the first phalanx- here- sutured the tendons. Don’t know if it’s going to take- (beat) There was mustard on them. (beat) A paper bag. Best you could do?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: It's all we had... (beat) I answer mostly, on account that she can’t talk. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: What do you mean she can’t talk?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: She can’t.  28

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: She can’t? Is she deaf? Elisa signs

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Mute, sir. STRICKLAND’s ears prick up. He is suddenly interested- animated.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Mute. (points at scars) That what did it? Cut your voice box? Elisa signs. Zelda translates:

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: She sez: Since she was a baby...

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Who would do that to a baby? This world is sinful. Wouldn't you say, Dee-1i-lah (beat) Well- lemme say this upfront. He arranges the symmetry of his desk implements.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You clean that lab. You get out. Arranges the pens- turns towards Elisa.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The thing we keep in there, is an affront. Do you know what an affront is, Zelda?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Something offensive, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: That’s right- That’s right- And I should know. (beat) I've dragged that filthy thing- out of the river muck in South America and all the way here- (beat) And along the way we didn’t get to like each other much.  36-37 38 29 He takes two- three pain pills...

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You may think that thing looks human- Stands on two legs, but- we're created in the Lord’s image. And you don’t think that’s what the Lord looks like, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t know, Sir. What the Lord looks like.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Well, human, Zelda. He looks like a human. Just like me... Or even you. A little more like me, I guess... A RED PHONE rings. He picks up. STRICKLAND (CONT’D) General Hoyt. Thank you for calling me back. Signals them to leave.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am, Sir- much better. Pain pills, is all- Thank You. Two fingers, yes- but still got my thumb, my trigger and my pussy finger- (laughs) Yes, Sir- That's right- Looking forward to your visit, Sir. Decisions have to be made about the asset, Sir. From his window he watches as- -POV: Elisa walks away.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 36-37
dialogues.text: EXT. STRICKLAND’S NEIGHBORHOOD - DAWN 38 Fleming is pulling in. He drives a bottle green, jet-finn Sedan. Strickland climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Pick me up tonight. Nine thirty.  39

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Twenty one hundred and thirty hours- yes, Sir. Strickland gives him a look. Moves away. The Milk Truck is going by. A UNIFORMED MILKMAN is leavin cream and milk at his doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: I'll take that. Strickland picks it up. INT. STRICKLAND’S HOME - EARLY MORNING 30 39 All around, however, half-open moving cardboard boxes. No everywhere. Breakfast chatter- the TV is on (A COOKING SH At the table: Strickland- drinks milk straight from the bottle, tense as fuck- his wife ELAINE and their two kids TIMMY, 8 and TAMMY, 6. She places, in front of him, a product-placement-picture- perfect omelette.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: No pancakes? ‘TIMMY Dad? Guess what?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I've gone through half the boxes. Can't find the griddle. But I made you cheese and broccoli omelette, Sweetie, your favorite. Strickland clumsily- painfully- eats, grunts. ‘TIMMY Hey, Dad- Guess what? Guess what?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE,
dialogues.text: Are you feeling any better? Does it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Just a little. Pills help. ‘TIMMY Guess what? We are burying a time capsule- at the new school. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I wanted to ask you- Do you think we’ll all have jet packs, in the future?

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: That's right, Son. The future is bright. You gotta trust in that. This is America. Grunt. Strickland wolfs down his food. Elaine leans in.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Wash your hands real good sweetie. And come upstairs...

dialogues.speaker: LATER 40
dialogues.text: Strickland throws the Omelette in the garbage. Takes a pi with his milk. Grabs a cookie. He washes his hand at the sink. Turns off the TV Strickland climbs the steps. INT. STRICKLAND’S BEDROOM - DAY al Elaine closes the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I kinda like it here. The kids like the lawn. Plus- Dc is just half an hour away, isn’t it? He shows her his hands: clean. She smells one and kisses bandaged fingers. Pulls out a breast and allows the clean hand to touch it.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: It’s still Baltimore, Blaine- Strickland mounts ELAINE. Rhythmic. Mechanical. Like an athlete training for a competitive sport. His face shows emotion.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Oh- He sees her neck - touches it, traces lines

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Richard-- He covers her mouth. Keeps pumping. She tries to talk.  41a 42 43 44 45 32

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Shh- Silence. Don’t talk. I want you in silence.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Honey- your hand’s bleeding- oh-

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Shh- Shh- in silence. He interrupts her with a vigorous thrust. In and out like piston pump. Presses his hand. She looks up at him, confu He pushes her face away from him. And pumps harder. INT. LAB - DUSK 41a Alone, the Amphibian Man tries to reassemble the broken eggshells. Signs: “egg” INT. ELISA’S APARTMENT - DUSK 42 Elisa takes 5 hardboiled eggs out of the pot of water. Elisa readies a portable turntable. Grabs a record from a collection of dozens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa enters the lab. Starts cleaning a mess around the operating table. Hoffstetler is changing in the B.G. Toss his lab coat into a tall and narrow laundry cart. Leaves, along with the last lab assistant. Elisa places the eggs by the edge of the pool. Excitedly she takes some LP records (from a carrier) and portable player. The creature emerges slowly from the water. Takes and egg starts peeling it. Elisa shows him the record and signs: “record”  46 47 33 He is curious and vigilant. Watches her carefully as she takes the record and plays it: Glenn Miller’s LOVER'S

dialogues.speaker: SERENADE
dialogues.text: His bioluminescent markings light up. She lifts the needle. Music stops. The creature reacts as if to magic. Needle down, music back: Excitement!! Markings light up!! The creature admires the music, tries to snatch it mid-ai She smiles- He smiles back

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 46
dialogues.text: MONTAGE a7 -Five eggs. Boiling. Dancing slowly in the water. -Elisa sets all five Boiled Eggs on the edge of the pool. -The creature emerges. Does the sign for “egg”. -Elisa chooses new records. -Her locker room is filling up with LP’s -Elisa travels on the bus with more eggs and records. -Elisa mops- a smile on her face. Zelda watches, concerne -Elisa readies her bath- mesmerized by the water. -Giles watches as Elisa “borrows” extra eggs from his fri -Elisa packs all 7,8,9 eggs in her paper bag. -Elisa shows a new record to the creature in the cylinder -She mops while the music plays Quietly, Hoffstetler enters the lab just as the song ends The Amphibian Man bangs on the glass to ELISA and signs: “play a different record.” His markings brighten.  48 49 49a

dialogues.speaker: 49B
dialogues.text: 34 ELISA signs- asking him to “point.” The AMPHIBIAN MAN poi Elisa turns the record around. “MOONGLOW” by Benny Goodma plays. Elisa dances in front of the cylinder. The AMPHIBIAN MAN swims, delighted! Elisa walks over and puts one hand up against the glass, slowly, the creature puts a hand up “against” hers. His markings active and color- changing. Her smile turns wistful. She keeps her hand there. Leans forehead on the glass. Hoffstetler watches- a tray of raw fish in his hands- Mesmerized. Moved. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOFFSTETLER Arrives in a YELLOW CAB. Climbs the steps of building. AN OLD MATRON smokes watches children play outs

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: Good morning Mrs. Peabody, how is the gout? She signals “So-so” INT. HOFFSTETLER’S APARTMENT - DAY 49 Austere. Impersonal. Hoffstetler lights a cigarette- look out the window to- EXT. STREET POV - DAY 49a -the empty street. INT. HOFFSTETLER’S APARTMENT - SAME 498 -He grabs a small pen knife from his desk and gets on his hands and knees. He uses it to lift a set of floorboards. They reveal a ne fitting BLACK CASE. He opens the case: a passport, a LEATHER NOTEBOOK, some equipment, cash, etc. He takes a set of blueprints.  50 51 52 53 54 35

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding a manila envelope, DR. HOFFSTETLER smokes a cigarette. He is sitting on a concrete block in an indust distribution centre. Looking at his watch. A Dark SEDAN s a BURLY RUSSIAN climbs out of the passenger seat and head toward him.

dialogues.speaker: BURLY RUSSIAN
dialogues.text: The sparrow nests on the window sill.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BURLY RUSSIAN
dialogues.text: The sparrow nests on the window sill.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: And the eagle takes the prey-

dialogues.speaker: BURLY RUSSIAN
dialogues.text: (in Russian) Uhhh. What? Hoffstetler sighs. Gets up.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: (in Russian) That’s the password: “And the Eagle takes the Prey” Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BURLY RUSSIAN enters the car. Hoffstetler is squeezed tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE RUSSIAN VIOLINISTS, dressed in “authentic” Gipsy ga play Ochi Chernye in a “classy” Russian restaurant. HOFFSTETLER and BURLY RUSSIAN enter and head for-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiters come in an out of a busy kitchen. Sitting in front of a HUGE LOBSTER TANK: LEO MIHALKOV, a severe man with slow, deliberate speech (in Russian with subtitles) drinks vodka and smokes. Hoffstetler & BURLY RUSSIAN enter.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: “Bob.” How are you? The group laughs. Not Hoffstetler. He responds in flat bu fluent, unaccented Russian.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: I was sitting like a moron on a concrete block in the middle of nowhere for an hour. I took three taxis to get there. Again. (looks at Burly) Why can’t we just meet here? It’s the same restaurant every time!!

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: I could change my mind.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: But you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: But I could- (pours a drink) So- Tell us, “Bob"-

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: Dimitri, Comrade- Not “Bob." Who names himself with one syllable? Dimitri/Hoffstetler offers him his notebook: in it diagra and anatomical notes. Hoffstetler hands him the Blueprints.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: What is this, Dimitri? Sit- sit-

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: Anatomical notes- and- Layout of the laboratory where the asset is being studied. Everything we need for the extraction.  37

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: I will pass it on to the directorate. Mihalkov opens a bottle of vodka. Pours.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Distilled four times- arrives by diplomatic valise. Minsk. Isn’t that your hometown?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: We must do it as soon as possible- (beat) This creature, Mihalkov- I think it may be able to communicate.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: Communicate.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: With us. I have reason to believe it is intelligent. It- it responds to language- to music... (beat) Will you please pass that up also?

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: I will. A WAITER brings three plates of steaming lobster tails an filet mignon and a pot of butter. The Burly Russian eats. MIHALKOV (CONT’D) Now- eat, Dimitri. They call this “Surf—"

dialogues.speaker: BURLY RUSSIAN
dialogues.text: “,..and Turf”.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: “surf and Turf” A feast. They boil the lobsters right here. They squeak a little but they are so soft and sweet. KISSING MY BABY GOODBYE by Jon Erik Kellso starts. 55aA OMITTED 55aA  55a 56 56a 57 38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa checks her time card. Strickland- calmly smoking a cigarette- watches her. She sneaks an uncomfortable glanc He smiles. She moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELISA and ZELDA sort the towels, lab coats and dirty line into thin, tall laundry carts. YOLANDA and 3 OTHERS do as much. Elisa fills up itemized sheets- tears them up and puts th in the bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Loading Dock where there is a LAUNDRY TRUCK. They load the soiled sheets and towels. Nearby- A couple of African American and Latin workers ar smoking. A cafeteria worker (Duane) offers a drag-

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Hey, Zelda, want a smoke?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: That shit’s not good for you, Duane.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Feels good.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: It does, doesn’t it? She looks at Elisa.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C'mon Elisa, just one. Elisa shakes her head, looks at a VIDEO CAMERA above them

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: They can’t see us, they push that camera up at break time. With the broom-  58 59 39 Lou points at a dirty broom.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: This here’s a blind spot.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Hey, Elisa, how come you always taking all them boiled eggs at the cafeteria? Can’t nobody eat seven eggs a day.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA,
dialogues.text: Mind your own, Duane. Leave her alone.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Girl can’t speak but she sure can eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa pushes her cart down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa enters the lab with her cart and equipment. Closes behind her- hears a plaintive whimper- not unlike that of whale. Much to her surprise- The Amphibian Man is on a plinth. Chained to a large METAL PLATE ON THE FLOOR. Chains on hi neck and arms, force him to kneel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. She looks around: Surgical instruments a ready. Lights are centered on the creature. The creature howls in pain- gasping. Elisa drops her lunc bag- -an egg rolls out- She moves closer- tries to free him when- CLACK! The DOOR begins to OPEN. She picks up her stuff an hides. Strickland ENTERS. Removes his jacket. Pops a few sticks gum in his mouth. Pulls out the cattle prod. The creature howls for help. Strickland raises the cattleprod.  60 40

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Miss me? I took a candy break. This? Is it this that scares you? You should be used to it by now... He shocks the creature.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you are again. Making that god-awful sound. Is that you crying? Is that what it is? You hurting? Huh? Or maybe you're angry? Yeah. Maybe you'd like to get another bite at me. Elisa watches him go over to the plinth, staring down the creature. The creature's fins “fluff up” and change colors. It hiss Strickland sucks his candy and cattleprods it- makes it g wild.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t tell- Are you begging? ‘Cause to me it’s just the worst fucking noise I’ve ever heard. Elisa's horrified to realize she left one of the BOILED E out. It’s inches from Strickland’s foot. He kicks it. It rolls. Strickland picks up the egg. Looks around. Elisa hides, she can barely breathe. cur TO: INT. CORRIDOR “B” - SAME 60 ZELDA pushes her cart down the corridor. Sees Elisa's abandoned. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Elisa? HOFFSTETLER goes by in a Golf cart. By his side: a FIVE S GENERAL, Fleming and a group of MP’s and technicians awai 14. cur TO:  61 41

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strickland walks towards the bank of medical monitors. Elisa tenses. The door opens. Hoffstetler et al, enter.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: General Hoyt! Welcome, Sir! Everything’s ready. Good to have you here, Sir! Technicians pour in. Elisa hides.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOYT
dialogues.text: Good God. Is that it? (matter of fact) Much bigger than I pictured.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Ain't that something? Ugly as sin. The natives in the Amazon worshipped it-

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOYT
dialogues.text: Well- It sure doesn’t look like much of a God right now, does it? Strickland takes a pill or two. Hoffstetler Examines the creature: BLOOD in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: They were primitives, sir. Tossed offerings into the water; flowers, fruits, crap like that... Tried to stop the oil drill with bows and arrows. That didn’t end too well.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: What happened? He's bleeding. You cannot keep doing this-

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: It's an animal, Hoffstetler. Just keeping it tame. Elisa watches from her hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOYT
dialogues.text: (flips through folder) “Oxygen osmosis- dioxide exchange.” What are we lookin’ at here, Son?  42

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: This creature, Sir- I’ve never seen anything like like it. Ever. It can alternate between two entirely separate breathing mechanisms...

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Mudskipper can do that.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: You want to put a man in space for days, weeks even, he’s going to have to endure conditions the human body just wasn’t made for. But this- This means long-term survivability in space. This gives us an edge against the Soviets.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOYT
dialogues.text: How long can it breathe outside the water? STRICKLAND shows him a CHRONOMETER. Ticking.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Really- Thirty minute intervals. It’s been out now, about... twenty eight- so we should start to see the effects. They wait. The creature suffers. STRICKLAND (CONT’D) Reality, is, Sir- We don’t know jackshit about this thing-

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOYT
dialogues.text: Soviets want it- We know that much. Those cockeyed bastards- They send a dog up into space- We get a laugh. But next thing we know- they send a human up -- a Ruskie, orbiting our planet, doing God knows what? And then who's laughing? Krushchev. That’s who- We let him put a dog in space, he laughs, puts a commie in space, he laughs, puts missiles in Cuba. Have we learned nothing?

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Give'm a dog, they take Cuba.  43

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOYT
dialogues.text: You got that right. They laugh. The creature spasms in pain.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: Sir. I would advise- They watch as the creature struggles to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We need to get him back in the water-—

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Let us go over the mark for once, See where it takes us. The creature starts convulsing. Elisa steps out from behi the monitors, ready to act. Hoffstetler sees her. His eye stop her. Strickland waits: looks at the chronometer. STRICKLAND (CONT’D) Scientists- they are like artists: They fall in love with their playthings. He looks right at the creature, who’s gasping, in agony. second hand on the chronometer crosses the minute mark. STRICKLAND (CONT’D) Now- Over here, Sir- right here- you see? (mirror signals his ribcage) The creature has a thick jointed cartilage separating the primary and secondary lungs- Am I explaining this correctly, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Yes- but we’ve been able to get-

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: It makes the X-rays inconclusive...

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: In principle, yes but, See? This-  44

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Sir- If we want to get the edge on the Soviets- and I know we can- we have to vivisect this thing. Take it apart. Learn how it works.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: No- no- That would defeat the purpose- The creature faints and releases a large pool of urine on slab. Elisa, watching, is in agony, barely able to restrain herself.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir? He’s passed out- Please. General Hoyt glances at Strickland, who checks the stopwa and shrugs. Relieved, Hoffstetler gives the signal, and the techs rus around the creature. He uses his keys to free it from the collar and manacles.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put him in the tank- The tank. Let him pressurize. (beat) General Hoyt, Sir: You cannot- under any circumstance- kill this creature. You cannot-

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOYT
dialogues.text: Count these with me, Son- there’s five of them: That means I can do whatever the hell I want. You wanna plead your case? I'll listen (beat) But, end of the day, it is my damn decision. The three of them leave. Elisa steps out. Follows them. INT. CORRIDOR “B” (GREEN SCREEN) 62

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: What were you doing in there?? What were you doing in there

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 64 45 Zelda is frantic. Grabs Elisa by the arm. Pulls her away.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? Are you out of your damn mind? (beat) I will not lose my job. God knows the last time Brewster brought home a dollar... Elisa looks around with utter impotence. She signs.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If your involved- I'll get blamed! I'll get sacked!! Yes- i will be!! Elisa signs.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just to be on the safe side. I’m black! They don’t need any other reason- Elisa walks away- grabs a bucket and a pail.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So listen to me: I am not covering for you, you hear! You shouldn’t be in there when you shouldn't be in there- And that is that. INT. COMMAND CENTER / STRICKLAND’S OFFICE - SAME 64 Elisa enters the command center- grabs a trash bin and watches- -as GENERAL arguing with Strickland and Hoffstetler. Elisa climbs the steps. Watches- -reads their lips- As they move around, the subtitles pop in and out. STRICKLAND: Untamed- dangerous-

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: (complete line) That thing is untamed- Dangerous-  64a 65-67 67a 673 46 HOFFSTETLER: No. We cannot kill it- We cannot-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russian infiltration- STRICKLAND (CONT’D) (complete line) Every day we keep it here, we risk Russian infiltration. We should get it over with. HOFFSTETLER: No- we must- please-

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: No- we must wait- please. The General thinks, facing the window and then turns and delivers his answer. A beat. Hoffstetler is upset. Elisa pretends to pick up trash. Looks up: The General an Strickland go by.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOYT
dialogues.text: Crack the damn thing open. Learn what you can and close shop here. Give yourself a good pat in the back, Strickland. You've done it.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sir. She looks up: Hoffstetler stands alone in the glass offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The creature floats gently. Blood flows from his side

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: (prelap) Get him out:

dialogues.speaker: 67E
dialogues.text: 68 47 OMITTED 67c

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 67E
dialogues.text: INT. GILES’ APARTMENT - DAWN 68

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? No- No- Absolutely not. (she signs) Because it is breaking the law! That's why. Giles is getting dressed- in his best suit. He grooms him incessantly, checks his elbows for wear. Readjusts the ha

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're probably breaking the law right now, just- talking about it. He walks away. She runs in front of him. Stops him: Signs Giles translates. She signs. GILES (CONT’D) Alone? What if he’s alone? What about it? We’re all alone! If I- If I took you to a Chinese restaurant- would you save every crab? (beat) “It's the loneliest thing you've ever seen...” Well there you go- you just said it. It’s a thing- A freak- GILES (CONT’D) I understand what you’re- Pushes him. Signs.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK, OK, calm down- I'11 repeat it- to you. (repeating out loud) “and what am I? I move my mouth - like him- and I make no sound- like him. What does that make me?” (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) “All that I am, all that I’ve been- ever- brought me here- to him.” (beat) “Him??" What are you talking about? That thing? It’s a “him” now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes him and re-signs, violently: “HIM”

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Watch it! (beat) “The way he looks at me. He doesn’t know what I lack... Or how I am incomplete. He just sees me for what I am. As I am. And he is happy to see me, every time. Every day.” (beat) “and now I can either save him now or let him die. Never see his eyes, see me again. I will not let that. go...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her hands.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am leaving- stop talking. This is important for me, Elisa- Maybe a second chance for me- I have to go- He picks up the illustration.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when I come back I- We will not talk about this. Again. There’s nothing we can do. What are we, Elisa? You and I? Nothing. What can we do? Nothing. (beat) And- I am sorry. But it is not even human. She trembles in rage as she signs. Subtitled: “If we don’ something... Neither are we.” 69-72 omrrreD 69-72

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Giles!  73 49

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Hey- I was waiting- BERNIE. I know, I’m sorry-

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: We're going in?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Not right this second- you're early.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: No. It’s Monday. You said Monday-

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: I know- I know I said that- You should’ve just mailed the art.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Why? I wanted to show it to you. To the team- In person. It’s some of my best work-

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: This is not a good time. Maybe later. Giles figures it out.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Sure. No problem. What time is good for you, Bernie? Bernie removes his eyeglasses. Saddened. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giles drinks milk on the counter. By his side: his art.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: You painted that? He comes to Giles table, carrying a slice of pie. Giles n PIE GUY (CONT’D) Wowee- You're good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as good as a photograph, apparently. But it is good, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Pfft- I couldn’t paint that. Here: on me. Serves him the pie.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: For me?

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: It's not key lime- but it’s good.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: ‘Thank You.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Don't mention it. We don’t get many like you in here. You seem very educated. I like talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Oh, well- The thing is... That’s the thing, I really come here for- mostly- For the-

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: The conversation... And the pie is mighty fine, ain’t it?

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: OH, mmmh- I work alone and my best friend is not much of a... conversationalist. An African-American couple with their kid, enters.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: See? That's part of the job here. Like being a bartender. You serve people pie, listen to their problems. Get to know them. Quickly, before he loses his nerve, Giles reaches out and sets his hand on top of one of Pie Guy’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: I would like- to know you. Better.  51 Pie Guy, beginning to get a glimmer of what’s going on, slowly pulls his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Old man? Giles realizing his mistake, freezes.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: er- you- bought me pie.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: I bought pie- For everyone. ‘cause I got engaged last night. To that. young lady over there. Points at a YOUNG WAITRESS.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: I see... The Pie Guy addresses the African-American family.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: Hey, no- Not the counter- Just take out. You can’t sit there. You want something, you order, you take it out.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: But it’s empty... The counter is-

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: All reserved. All day. You don’t sit down. The family leaves. PIE GUY (CONT’D) “Y'all come back, ¥’hear?”

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: You don’t have to talk to them like that.

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: You should leave too. And don’t come back. This is a family restaurant. Giles spits the pie. Starts leaving. PIE GUY (CONT’D) Hey- You left this-  74 52 Picks up Giles painting

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: No. Keep it. It’s perfect for you. (beat) I- I never understood why they are so damn happy anyway. So happy about a- slab of animal... protein- in- in that shade of green- that should come with a warning label.. (beat) But I guess they smile because that is their future- Your future. Just like your pies- These horrible pies. Turning around in their nice, shiny glass towers- But tasting like ashes in my mouth. Have you ever seen a real key lime pie? It’s not green. It’s actually beautiful. Who makes these pies’ Who makes them?? What are they- really? Shit. Bright, fake-colored shit. Made by no one. Eaten by no one... You don’t even know where they come from... Do you? You don’t even know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves

dialogues.speaker: PIE GUY
dialogues.text: They come from Albany, Faggot. cur To: INT. ELISA’S APARTMENT - DAY 74 Elisa scrubs her bathtub clean. A knock on the door. She opens: it’s Giles.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: I have... no one else- you are the only person that I can talk to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa is moved. Signs “Me, too...”

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatever this thing is... You need it... So- Just tell me what to do.  75 76 53 They embrace. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffstetler waits. Smoking. The car arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main room of the restaurant now. Empty.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: Moscow will not support your plan. Too risky. Too soon.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: What--

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: There is not enough time.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: But I have told you, they will kill it-- And it is sentient. I am sure of that now. Did you tell them that?

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: And? (beat) I can do it. Myself and two operators.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: No. MIHALKOV pulls out a small black steel case and places a SMALL, CLOCKWORK DRIVEN DEVICE- a “Popper” (we will see i action soon).

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have only two choices, Dimitri, One: You must delay the procedure, a week, minimum...  54

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: That is not possible.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: I understand. Which brings us up to option two. Takes the “Popper.” MIHALKOV (CONT’D) Israeli “Popper”- you set it next to a fuse box- it will buy you five to ten minutes in the dark: no cameras- no containment doors- Then- Opens the small case. Inside: two syringes full of silver liquid.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You inject it with this-

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: Inject it?

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: Kill it. Destroy it- Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: I came to this country- to learn what I could- as a patriot, yes- but also as a scientist. This creature- It should not be killed. Not by them. Not by us. (beat) There is still so much we can learn- He pushes the syringe box towards Mihalkov.

dialogues.speaker: MIHALKOV
dialogues.text: We don’t need to learn. We need Americans not to learn. They don’t learn, we win. Mihalkov pushes the syringe box back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRICKLAND is admiring a beautiful Cadi 1962 Coupe: All F Jet tail lights. Sleek metal body.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Cadillac DeVille. Best car ever made. V8, 390 CID, clean, crisp like a fresh dollar bill. Climb right in-

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: I am just idling around. The Dealer (blue suit, blue tie) opens the door using a b handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: AM/EM stereo sound, Air conditioner, power windows, power breaks, power steering, power seats... (beat) All deluxe interior appointment choices. 143 options. The Taj-Mahal on wheels.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: I’m not sure about the green.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Not green, my friend. (beat) Teal.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Well, Teal looks green to me.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: But it isn’t, see? It’s a limited edition. Twelve coats of paint. Polished by hand. All authentic chrome detailing. Four out of five successful men in America drive a Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: That a fact?

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: This here is the future. And you strike me as a man who is heading there.  788

dialogues.speaker: 78B
dialogues.text: 78c 78CaA

dialogues.speaker: 78CA
dialogues.text: 78cc 78cD 56

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Why- The Future. You are the man of the future. (beat) You belong in this car. Strickland climbs in. CHICA CHICA BOOM starts in the soundtrack. cur TO:
-STRICKLAND drives his brand new car. He smiles. Other Ca honk at him. -Drivers give him the “thumbs up” -He is in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE
dialogues.text: He lays the paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OMITTED 78CcC - GILES PULLS THE STENCIL AND ADMIRES HIS HANDIWORK. 78cD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses the parking lot, like a king- -and goes by the smoking employees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa empties a paper basket. In the B.G. Hoffstetler and other SCIENTISTS monitor the creature on the gurney. Elisa approaches a small door in the far side of the lab- marked SERVICE CORRIDOR. Hoffstetler watches her surreptitiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Elisa peeks at the narrow service corridor. Walks through it. Emerges into-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the loading dock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZELDA smokes her cigarette with the gang. She watches as Elisa enters the dock and looks at the VIDEO CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music carries on. On TV, Carmen Miranda dances.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: So I will drive down the loading dock- at exactly 05:00 am. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shifts are changing, yes- So we have... Elisa signs: “FIVE”

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...five minutes... Five A.M. Five, five. Give me your watch. You'll move the camera... We’ll synchronize our watches. Just like the movies. (beat) I’m so proud of you. You're not afraid. (Elisa signs) Oh, you are? Very? Don’t tell me that! I’m terrified! Giles finishes reproducing Elisa’s ID card, using his ski as a draftsman. He holds up the finished 1D.

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think it’s some of my best work. Then he glues his own picture and fills the name- GILES (CONT’D) Michael Parker. A good, trustworthy name. Bit butch... Loads it in a typewriter: fills in date of birth, etc. GILES (CONT’D) Age? I thought- fifty one? Elisa looks at him. GILES (CONT’D) Fifty four? Silence. Uses Ink to turn the “1” into a "7". GILES (CONT’D) Oh, you know? There is no need to be rude: Fifty seven- I put the hair on, I can pull it off. now- He models two sweaters. GILES (CONT’D) This one or this one? I think this one says “Working Man” and Move Thor! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 sla 59

dialogues.speaker: GILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This one- with butterscotch “tie- says “casual but with stylish”. 1 agree. Then we/re ready. cur TO: INT. STRICKLAND’S OFFICE - NIGHT 81 Music ends. Strickland stands in front of his wall of monitors- checking every detail. He eats little candy. Spots Elisa cleaning in a corridor. Eats candy. Drops a glass of water- on purpose. Presses a intercom

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Sally- could you send Mrs. Esposito up to clean a spill? INT. STRICKLAND’S OFFICE - NIGHT B1A Elisa cleans. Strickland eats candy.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: You know...? I can’t figure it out myself- you're not much to look at, but- go figure- I keep thinking about you. (beat) And I’ve seen you, looking at me. You've been- looking at me? He peruses his bag of candy. Offers her some.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When you say you’re mute... Are you entirely silent? Or do you squawk a little? Some mutes squawk. Not. pretty, but- She gathers her implements and gets ready to leave. He catches her. He touches the scars on her neck.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should know this: I don’t mind the scars. Don’t mind that you can’t speak, either. Uses his fingernail to scrape a small piece of candy from gum.  82-83

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) When you come right down to it- I like it. A lot. Kind of gets me going... (beat) Thought you should know these things. She walks away.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! (beat) Bet I can make you squawk a little. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa (bucket in hand) enters the locker room- crosses Ze on the way out.

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Hurry up, Honey- I want to be home early. Elisa looks at her watch: 4:50 She steels herself and marches out. INT. MEN’S BATHROOM STALL - SAME 84 Hoffstetler opens the metal case with the syringe. Readie it. Puts it back in and into his pocket. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elisa uses the broom to push the camera slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffstetler marches towards Strickland’s office.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: We need to delay the procedure. Strickland is reading a book by Norman Vincent Peale.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Knock first.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Knock before entering my office.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: This is urgent-

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Go back out. Knock. Then I/1l let you in and we'll talk. That’s the protocol. Follow the protocol. In spite of himself, Hoffstetler obeys. Knocks.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come in. Hoffstetler enters. He is about to talk when-

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you get the door for me? Hoffstetler closes the door. STRICKLAND (CONT’D) See? That is the way. Now- Now we can talk.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: I need more time.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: We shouldn’t kill this creature...  62

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Look- Don't let the fact that you feel like a loser now, that your competitive tendencies have been engaged—

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: I'm not competitive! I don't want an intricate, beautiful thing destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Don’t let that cloud your judgement-

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: You're like a child with a transistor radio, you think if you smash it open you can look at the inside, see how it works. But you can't. It's smashed. It doesn’t work. You kill the music.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Bob- I don't hear you. Music? That thing dies. You learn. I leave. Out of here. Settle down. My family settles down. Somewhere. Nicer. Real. A real city.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: This creature- and I am certain of this- Is intelligent. Capable of language, of understanding- emotions. Long beat. Minuscule shrug and then:

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: So are the Soviets, the Gooks- and we still kill them, don’t we? Bottom line is, this is not a petting zoo- And I don't want to be in this shithole any longer than I need. Do you? Hoffstetler sees the camera MOVE on the loading docks. Strickland remains unaware.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFSTETLER
dialogues.text: No, Sir, I don’t.  90 91 92-93 93a

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: A-ha- So I made it so we both win. You can thank me later. SING, SING, SING by Benny Goodman starts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoffstetler sees the broom and the camera. He gets it. He hurries-

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 92-93
dialogues.text: INT. LAUNDRY AREA - SAME 93a Elisa packs a laundry cart with wet towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End of shift. Throngs of WORKERS heading out. Everybody e is punching in. Zelda looks around.

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: Hey- what are you waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: ZELDA
dialogues.text: Have you seen Elisa? Yolanda rolls her eyes. The elevator starts beeping. Zeld signals her to “go.” She looks at the “OUT” cards- Elisa’s still in. She punches it and- -heads back into the complex. OMITTED 93c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
